awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Atmospheric Nanoparticle Growth from Nitrate (NO3) Radical Initiated Oxidation of Monoterpenes
awd_abstract_narration:
This project combines the results of laboratory studies with numerical modeling to investigate the growth of tiny nanoparticles in the atmosphere. It is important to understand the growth of these tiny particles because they can influence the formation and properties of cloud droplets. This research will lead to the development of a mechanistic model to better predict the influence of aerosol on climate and air quality.  

Laboratory experiments will be conducted to identify and quantify the gas- and particle-phase products of the reactions of NO3 radicals with three common monoterpenes: α-pinene, β-pinene, 3-carene, and an additional compound, α-thujene, which is structurally similar to α-pinene and should likewise form gas phase products that contribute minimally to nanoparticle growth. These experiments will be conducted for a range of NO3 concentrations, humidities, and temperatures. Computational chemistry studies will provide insight into possible reaction mechanisms and nanoparticle growth due to monoterpene oxidation by NO3 radicals.

The three objectives of the project are: (1) Implement computational chemistry methods for elucidating reaction pathways and developing CIMS detection strategies; (2) Perform comparative laboratory studies of NO3 radical initiated oxidation of monoterpenes; and (3) Obtain chemical closure between gas phase precursors and nanoparticle physicochemical properties. The process-level model for nanoparticle growth, developed through this project, will be tested using experimentally measured growth rates. Nanoparticle growth is directly tied to the ability of these particles to influence cloud condensation nuclei populations and affect the formation and properties of cloud droplets.  

This collaborative project includes a "near-peer" program that pairs University of California at Irvine graduate students with Reed College undergraduates in order to facilitate scientific interactions and to prepare the undergraduates for graduate study.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project combined modeling with laboratory experiments in order to understand and the unique chemical pathways responsible for the growth of 5 - 50 nm diameter particles (referred to here as nanoparticles) from reactions of monoterpenes with nitrate (NO3) radical. Prior studies, including those performed by the PIs, have shown a remarkable variability in nanoparticle formation and growth for many monoterpenes that are commonly emitted from plants, including a-pinene, which was found to form very few nanoparticles, and b-pinene and d-carene, which readily formed new particles. Our investigations focused on these three monoterpenes along with a-thujene, which is structurally similar to a-pinene but has never been studied previously.

Two lab and modeling studies were performed in pursuit of our research goals. In the first, we developed a computationally-derived mechanism detailing the nitrate radical-initiated oxidation of d-carene. These predicted products from our derived mechanism were compared to compounds observed in the gas phase during chamber experiments in our laboratory. Those experiments showed products consistent with each of the three types of intramolecular reactions we predicted to be important from our computational mechanism. In the second study, we performed chamber experiments to measure the composition of the gas phase reaction products of nitrate radical initiated oxidation of the four monoterpenes mentioned previously. Total organic yield, effective oxygen-to-carbon ratio, and dimer-to-monomer ratio correlated with observed particle formation for the monoterpene systems with some exceptions. The d-carene system produced the most particles, followed by b-pinene, with the a-pinene and a-thujene systems producing no particles.

Models that represent particle formation from nitrate + monoterpene chemistry do not currently account for the wide variability in particle formation rates from different monoterpenes. This is due in large part to a lack of understanding as to the exact mechanisms that lead to the formation of low volatility gas phase products from this chemistry. Our studies provide a much-needed quantitative understanding of this process, and are key steps towards predicting growth rates of newly formed nanometer-sized particles in the atmosphere.

An additional activity supported by this grant was participation in a unique measurement campaign in 2019: SeaSCAPE (Sea Spray Chemistry And Particle Evolution) held at Scripps Institute for Oceanography. During SeaSCAPE, we assessed the impacts of inorganic and organic species on the mass fraction of ultrafine sea spray aerosol and compared these measurements to those of larger sea spray particles. We observed times when particles had significant inorganic mass fractions, primarily from sodium chloride, and times with minimal inorganic influence. Increased inorganic mass fractions correlated with low phytoplankton activity in seawater. Of organic compounds that our measurements were sensitive to, we saw clear fatty acid and polysaccharide signals in the ultrafine size range but not in particles larger than 100 nm in diameter.

To broaden the impact of this project, a "near-peer" mentoring program was launched. In fall 2018, 9 undergraduate students from Reed College who expressed interest in learning more about graduate studies in chemistry were matched with 9 UCI graduate student volunteer mentors. Each graduate/undergraduate pair met remotely and, in 8-9 August 2019, Reed students visited UCI for lab and campus tours, a round-table discussion with 4 UCI graduate students, faculty presentations, and a networking dinner. Feedback from the students on the UCI visit was very positive. Some mentoring pairs continued to communicate in 2020 as Reed students transitioned into graduate school or professional careers.
